conversation.content: [urgently] Listen carefully, we have maybe ten minutes before they trace this location through the security cameras. [speaking fast] Everything I taught you about pattern recognition, everything about reading micro-expressions and detecting surveillance, you're going to need it all starting tonight.

[anxiously] You said this was just a training exercise when you called, but you're bleeding through your jacket and your hands are shaking. [voice breaking] What happened at the facility, and why are they calling you a traitor on every encrypted channel?

[firmly] The facility was compromised three weeks ago, but not by foreign agents like they're claiming. [quieter] Our own people orchestrated the breach to cover up what they've been developing in the sub-basement labs, something that violates every treaty we've signed.

[confused] That doesn't make sense, Director Morrison signed off on all the lab protocols himself, and he's been with the agency for thirty years. [hesitantly] Are you saying he's part of whatever this conspiracy is?

[bitter] Morrison's been running this operation since before you were recruited. [exhales] The man who pinned your badge on you at graduation has been weaponizing cognitive enhancement drugs on unwilling test subjects, mostly prisoners nobody would miss.
[whispering] No.

[speaking fast] I have proof on this drive, medical records, video surveillance, financial transactions linking Morrison to black site facilities in four countries. [pause] But I need you to be the one who exposes it because they'll kill me before I can testify.

[shaky voice] You're asking me to destroy my entire career, to betray everyone I've worked with for the past five years. [frustrated] Even if what you're saying is true, they'll come after me the moment I access those files.

[warmly] You're the only one I trained who never lost their moral compass, even when following orders would have been easier. [proudly] That stubborn integrity of yours that used to drive me crazy during training scenarios, that's exactly why I'm trusting you with this.
[very quietly] How long have you known about this? [accusingly] How many operations did we run together while you were sitting on information about our own agency torturing people?

[regretful] Six months, and every day since I discovered the truth has been a calculation of when to act and who to trust. [sighs] I kept you in the dark to protect you, but now protection means giving you the power to fight back.

[desperately] There has to be another way, someone higher up we can report to, maybe the oversight committee or even the press directly. [speaking fast] We could leak it anonymously, keep both our names out of it completely.

The oversight committee members are getting kickbacks from the pharmaceutical contracts, and the two journalists who started investigating mysteriously died in separate car accidents last month. [firmly] This has to be done from the inside, with someone they won't immediately suspect.

[resigned] You've already decided you're not coming back from this, haven't you? [voice breaking] This meeting isn't about passing on information, it's you saying goodbye while pretending everything might work out fine.

[gently] I've got three passports, enough cash to last a decade, and a boat waiting at the marina that officially sank two days ago. [chuckles] Remember when you asked why I made you learn sailing during desert warfare training?

[crying while speaking] You paranoid bastard, you've been planning an exit strategy this entire time. [laughs] All those crazy survival scenarios you put me through, the dead drops, the emergency protocols, you were preparing me to lose you.

[very sincerely] Every mentor's job is to make themselves obsolete eventually, to train someone better than they ever were. [proudly] You're faster, smarter, and most importantly, you still believe this job can mean something good.

[determined] Fine, I'll take the drive, I'll find a way to expose Morrison and whoever else is involved. [firmly] But you have to promise me something in return, that you'll send proof of life every six months, even if it's just a blank postcard from nowhere.

[warmly] Look for postcards with birds on them, different species each time, and know that your old mentor is somewhere watching the sunrise over water. [pause] They're coming up the stairs now, so you need to go out the back while I buy you time.

[quickly] Thank you for choosing me, for seeing something worth saving in a rookie who couldn't even properly clear a room. [emotionally] I won't let you down, I promise you that, and when this is over, when it's safe, I'll find you wherever you're hiding.

scenario: A former government agent being hunted by their own agency meets with their protégé one last time to pass on crucial information before going into permanent hiding.
